sales.models module#

class sales.models.Sale(*args, **kwargs)#

Bases: django.db.models.base.Model

Define a Sale between two users.

The transaction is managed by an operator (which can the the sender directly if the sell is direct). Most of sale are between an User and the association (represented by the special User with username ‘AE ENSAM’).

Parameters

  • datetime – date of sell, mandatory.

  • sender – sender of the sale, mandatory.

  • recipient – recipient of the sale, mandatory.

  • operator – operator of the sale, mandatory.

NEW IMPLMENTATION :param content_type: :param module_id: :param module: :param shop: :param products:

NEW IMPLMENTATION :type content_type: :type module_id: :type module: :type shop: Shop object :type products: Product object

Note:

Initial Django Permission (add, change, delete, view) are added.

Bases: django.core.exceptions.ObjectDoesNotExist

content_type#

Accessor to the related object on the forward side of a many-to-one or one-to-one (via ForwardOneToOneDescriptor subclass) relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Child.parent is a ForwardManyToOneDescriptor instance.

This class also doubles as an accessor to the related object (similar to ForwardManyToOneDescriptor) by adding itself as a model attribute.

pay()#
products#

Accessor to the related objects manager on the forward and reverse sides of a many-to-many relation.

In the example:

class Pizza(Model):
    toppings = ManyToManyField(Topping, related_name='pizzas')

Pizza.toppings and Topping.pizzas are ManyToManyDescriptor instances.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Child.parent is a ForwardManyToOneDescriptor instance.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Parent.children is a ReverseManyToOneDescriptor instance.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

string_products()#

Return a formated string concerning all products in this Sale.

Returns

each __str__ of products, separated by a comma.

Return type

string

Note:

Why do Events are excluded ?

list(request)#
class sales.views.SaleList#

Bases: shops.mixins.ShopMixin, borgia.views.BorgiaFormView

View to list sales.

The sale are displayed for a shop. A manager of a shop can only see sales relatives to his own shop. Association managers can switch to see other shops.

Note:

only sales are listed here. Sales come from a shop, for other

types of transactions, please refer to other classes (RechargingList, TransfertList and ExceptionnalMovementList).

date_begin = None#
date_end = None#

class sales.views.SaleRetrieve#

Bases: sales.mixins.SaleMixin, borgia.views.BorgiaFormView

Retrieve a sale.

A sale comes from a shop, for other type of transaction, please refer to other classes (RechargingRetrieve, TransfertRetrieve, ExceptionnalMovementRetrieve).
